marklogic.body:
You'd be surprised: engineering students with less-than-stellar academic performance who rely solely on the merit of their degree and Gain no relevant work experience in their time in college are pretty screwed, too. Education should not be about buying into the academic meritocracy or planning for future payrolls, but instead about discovering a discipline that resonates with and empowers you, a discipline that you can integrate it into your life/being/activities outside the classroom. As students, it is our responsibility to find (or even create) relevant work/life experiences so that we can present ourselves as well-rounded, innovative, and passionate minds and, thus, don't get stuck as a Burnt-out barista (even if it that happens to be where we start).
I'm interested to see whether people think my being an engineering student totally invalidates what I just said.
